Net worth is a measure of your financial health. It\'s calculated by subtracting your total liabilities (what you owe) from your total assets (what you own).

Assets include:
- Liquid assets (cash, savings, checking accounts)
- Investment assets (stocks, bonds, real estate investments)
- Retirement assets (401(k), IRAs, pensions)
- Personal assets (home, car, jewelry, collectibles)

Liabilities include:
- Short-term debts (credit cards, short-term loans, outstanding taxes)
- Long-term debts (mortgages, student loans, auto loans)

For example, if you have %1$s500,000 in assets and %1$s200,000 in liabilities, your net worth is %1$s300,000.

A positive net worth means you own more than you owe, which is a sign of financial stability. Tracking your net worth over time helps you measure your financial progress and make informed decisions about your money.

A mortgage is a loan used to purchase real estate, typically a home. The property itself serves as collateral for the loan, meaning the lender can take possession if you fail to make payments.

How it works: When you take out a mortgage, you borrow money to buy a property and repay it over a set period (usually 15-30 years) through monthly payments. Each payment includes:
- Principal: The amount borrowed
- Interest: The cost of borrowing
- Property Tax: Annual taxes divided into monthly payments
- Insurance: Homeowners insurance
- PMI: Private Mortgage Insurance (if down payment is less than 20%%)

For example, if you buy a home for %1$s300,000 with a %1$s60,000 down payment, you\'ll borrow %1$s240,000. At a 4%% interest rate over 30 years, your monthly payment (including taxes and insurance) will be approximately %1$s1,500.

A tax calculator helps you estimate your federal income tax liability based on your income, filing status, and deductions. This helps you plan your finances and avoid surprises at tax time.

How it works: Enter your annual income, filing status (Single, Married Filing Jointly, etc.), and deductions. The calculator estimates your tax liability using federal tax brackets and shows your effective tax rate.

For example, if you earn %1$s75,000 annually as a single filer with %1$s12,950 in standard deductions, your taxable income is %1$s62,050, resulting in approximately %1$s9,200 in federal taxes.
